Fixed.
When parsing filenames containing $nl$, we were making the assumption that 
your system language is of the form language_country (e.g. en_US), but in your 
case, it must have been just 'en' or 'de'.  No country.

>we were making the assumption that 
>your system language is of the form language_country (e.g. en_US), but in your 
>case, it must have been just 'en' or 'de'.  No country.

This statement is wrong, my locale is (taken from Help > About > Config Details):
osgi.nl=de_CH

I meant your 'target' NL.  what does it say on the PDE>Target 
Platform>Environment &JRE preference page?
-nl en_US and the log entry was in my dev .log ;-)

TargetPlatform.getNL() returned a string of two characters.  If you have not 
touched that preference page, TargetPlatform.getNL() returns Platform.getNL(). 
In any event, no matter what the length of the string is now, we won't choke 
on it.

Aside:
PDE always uses the environment values of your target for everything that you 
do in your host, since that is the target in which your workspace plugins will 
be tested and deployed.
This, for example, what allows you to use linux-gtk as host for example, and 
develop for linux-motif.  If we don't use your target os-arch-ws-nl in your 
host, the swt libraries for example (which contain $ws$ in their name) could 
not be located.

I figured out the problem.  I'm holding DJ personally responsible.  It has to 
do with preferences.

In PDECore.initializeDefaultPreferences(), I set the default for the target 
environment variables to be those of the currently running platform.

However, when i query the value of these variables later on, I sometimes don't 
get the default, I get "".  This caused the problem here.  More importantly it 
can cause compilation errors in plugins that have $ws$ in their library path, 
like swt.

Since resolving the target environment variables is in the critical path, I 
will no longer depend on the default preferences value.  It that returns "", I 
will yet again assign those of the current platform.
forgot to cc DJ.  It's no fun blaming him for stuff if he doesn't read it :-)
